comments.author: Lily Dalbkce

comments.text:
+Lily Dalbkce  The backbone network of the internet is all underground or 
undersea, and they use optical fibers, which do not conduct electricity at 
all, which means no electric current could be induced in them from solar 
flares even if they were above ground.

Comparing it to the telegraph lines over a hundred years ago is not a good 
comparation. What sort of protection against big voltage spikes did they 
have back then? What do we have now? Telegraph lines were relatively thin 
signal carriers, which would be mych more easily overloaded by the currents 
induced by a solar flare. The long power lines we use today have extremely 
much higher capacity than those telegraph lines had, and would not be as 
easily overloaded and catch fire. The lines that carry signals today are 
mostly below ground, where they are very well protected against 
electromagnetic pulses that would travel through the atmosphere.
comments.author: Ståle Helde

comments.text:
+Ståle Helde Minor solar flares. The last major solar flare was in the late 
1800s, where telegraphs started going crazy and started on fire and stuff. 
Luckily, that was the extent of their technology. If we had one of the 
magnitude (Which occurs about once every 150 years so we're due pretty 
quickly here) with our technology, the results would be devastating.
comments.author: Lily Dalbkce

comments.text:
+Lily Dalbkce Our current electricity-based society has lived through 
several solar flares already. We're protected well enough by the earth's 
electromagnetic field to not fry everything on the surface.

Really expensive computers are behind surge protectors, and laptops and 
cell phones won't be affected when they're not connected. They don't have 
long enough wires in them for a solar flare to induct a high enough voltage 
in them for them to stop working. We might get lots of power outages, but 
most of the important computers will survive. Sorry to ruin your doomsday 
scenario :p.
comments.author: Ståle Helde

comments.author: Lily Dalbkce

comments.text:
+Lily Dalbkce  The USB port is unproblematic. Assuming they were more 
advanced than we currently are, they would just hook the storage chip 
inside the USB device to a ton of wires and poke it with bits until they 
got something back. With enough processing power, they would eventually 
start to slowly reverse engineer our encoding formats. If they are 
extremely much more advanced than us, they might not even have to extract 
the information electronically. They might have a sort of scanner that 
could detect enough details inside the chip to just see the data stored 
there without having to send power through it at all.

Also, no data would be lost if the internet disappeared. You'd just not 
have an easy way of moving the data from one computer to another anymore. 
Even if you by "the internet" mean "every server connected to the 
internet", there are still plenty of personal computers with copies of 
things from the internet. There's quite a few people who have an entire 
text-copy of Wikipedia on an USB drive, for instance. Not the images, 
sadly. That would be a bit much. However, all the text on wikipedia is 
enough to describe a large amount of the world's history, discoveries, 
technology and culture. And, of course, there's a lot more stuff stored on 
home computers than just wikipedia. Piecing together everything, you'd have 
a lot of information even without the internet and its servers.
comments.author: Ståle Helde

comments.text:
And maybe future life made computers that have a USB port and accept our 
form of video. Not to mention translation issues. Our entire generation 
will be lost if the internet disappears because we don't have a whole lot 
of written papers. In fact, even papers don't last forever. The societies 
that will be easiest to learn about are those who used rock for their 
writing.
comments.author: Lily Dalbkce

top_comment.text:
Even if our sun mysteriously disappeared and the surface of the Earth 
froze, it would still take a very long time for the oceans to freeze 
completely. As miles of ice accumulated on the ocean surface, it would act 
an insulator that helped keep the deepest parts of the ocean as liquid 
water. Geothermic vents would continue to heat the bottom of the ocean, and 
microorganisms living on chemosynthesis would remain entirely unaffected by 
the disappearance of the sun. An ecosystem of underwater life would 
continue to persist on Earth even as the planet spent billions of years 
covered in a shell of ice, traveling through the void of space. And maybe 
some day, it would be caught in the gravitational pull of another star 
whose warmth would thaw the planet again, and life capable of living on the 
surface would evolve once more.﻿

comments.author: VEE727

comments.text:
I'm no physicist or anything BUT... the distance that Earth orbits the new 
sun would be relative to the difference between its properties vs that of 
our current sun. Basically, once the earth is ejected away when the sun 
disappears, it doesn't slow down for the billion years it takes to arrive, 
and the amount of force carrying the Earth would be the dependent variable 
on which you could calculate the distance to the new sun, based on its size 
and density. You could essentially calculate the difference between the 
active force of the new sun with that of the old sun to determine how long 
it would take for the Earth to slow down and establish a stable orbit.
Now, this is all assuming the Earth doesn't get within the proximity to any 
other large body of matter to alter it's course and speed before it gets to 
the new sun. However, the speed at which we are moving should determine the 
size that the new sun needs to be in order to get us to stop, which would 
be greater than or equal to that of our current sun.

+nintendodragon77 To answer your question in a less douchey way, life would 
most likely end up similar to the way life is today.  Eventually there 
would be fish and eventually they would start to walk on land.  Then there 
would be birds, but again this all would occur extremely slowly and over 
billions of years.  The reason life won't end up the same as it is today is 
that evolution is due to random genetic mutations and occasionally the 
mutation turns out to be a benefit to the species and thus makes it more 
likely to be passed on.  Obviously since these mutations happen randomly, 
there is no way life would be very similar but there still would be some 
sort of fish/land animals and birds.

comments.text:
+Scotchy Scotchy scotch Your reason for calling a different star 'Sun' 
doesn't make sense. If you wanted to convey that you meant another main 
sequence star of similar mass then you could have just plainly said that. 
You seem to be confused about terminology. Voyageur is not a satellite. 
Also, hundreds of thousands of supernovae occur daily. It hasn't been a 
couple months since the last, one likely occurred in the last couple 
minutes.

We don't need to go there to determine whether the laws are the same. We 
know the laws are the same in other galaxies due to the properties in the 
spectrum of light we collect from those galaxies.  Is there the possibility 
that they could change in the future or be different beyond our observable 
bubble? Sure, but the hypothetical star our planet could have come from 
wouldn't have come from the future or that far away.

You don't need to be so defensive, I wasn't attacking your idea, I was 
attempting to quantify it in a general sense. Posing hypothesis is 
pointless if you can't handle someone analysing it.

I haven't the slightest clue what you're saying about black holes. You seem 
thoroughly confused about what a theory is. String theory is not a theory, 
it is a hypothesis. It is unfortunate that it leads to this much confusion, 
they should have called it Model of strings. The Big Bang Theory isn't a 
guess. We know the universe is expanding from a smaller more dense form, 
it's Known. Not a guess.

Do you think forensic investigators just guess who did a crime too? The 
evidence tells you who did it.

For you to say you believe in a higher power just goes to show your 
irrationality. Your willing to accept something when there is no evidence 
to suggest it is true. You question things that are known and believe

comments.text:
(1) Star* not Sun. Sun is just a name for our Star.

(2) The closest galaxy is Andromeda, and it is 2.5 million light years 
away. Assuming Earth formed and was ejected from a star system there 10 
billion years ago means Earth would have to been travelling at 761km/s 
(average only, because it would have slowed down as it escaped Andromeda 
due to it's gravitational field and sped up later on due to the Milky Ways 
field) and that's if it got here today.

So if the star disappeared and we assume the planet was orbiting at about 
that velocity, the orbiting star must have been much more massive than our 
star now and we likely orbited much farther out than we do now. 

If for example we were to orbit our star at that velocity, ignoring the 
fact that we would actually just fling off into space, one year would be 
about 14 days.

Not an impossible event, but very implausible. Especially considering at 
that speed, the earth would not be able to settle into an orbit around the 
sun at this distance.

(3) I'm not even going to comment on that other scenario. lol

top_comment.text:
If the sun were to disappear as in "*poof* - It's gone". It would take ~8 
minutes for the earth to go dark, but we would know immediately that 
something was wrong because Earth would immediately fly out of orbit - like 
a slingshot. Gravity operates outside of space/time and is therefore 
instantaneous.

Hopefully, we'll rocket past the moon, rather than into it. GPS would 
immediately stop working, and at least 12 of those satellites would come 
crashing to Earth. In fact, every space satellite in our new trajectory 
would immediately come crashing down to Earth, the satellites on the far 
side of earth would be left behind, trailing in Earth's gravity.

Earthquakes would start moments later, due to the sudden gravitational 
shift. Some of our atmosphere will be lost, but much will remain. No 
worries, as most that atmosphere protected us from a sun that is no longer 
shining, or at least will stop shining within 7 minutes, 30 seconds...

Soon after we've gone dark, massive tidal waves will hit, because the 
oceans tides are no longer managed by the gravitational pull of the Moon. 
There will also likely be massive tsunami's as a result of the earthquakes.

Twitter would go nuts, and of course the New York Times would print "End of 
the World: Women and Minorities Hardest Hit"﻿

+James Kevin Quimbo My point is, as I've said before, you are anything but 
a credible source. You, somebody who has no sources material or 
peer-reviewed data to reference, are trying to tell me, somebody who writes 
and works on professional Physical and Planetary Geophysical topics daily, 
about how humans are progressing scientifically to colonise space in the 
near/far future.

The reasons that I'm not taking you seriously as somebody telling me that 
we need to colonise space are as follows:
Firstly you only talk in long drawn-out sentences about "what humanity 
really wants" and "survival of the race". Firstly, everything you say is 
strewn with a plethora of errors (eg human SPECIES, not RACE).
Secondly, and most importantly, you have no higher education in Physics, 
Planetary studies, Space, Rocket science etc. You know comparatively little 
about space travel, the cultural and economical issues associated and why 
we've been gathering data from other planets.

At no point did I say that we won't colonize space-we of course intend on 
doing so in the long term. You, however, seem to think that we need to do 
it asap, and also ramble on at a tangent about setting an example to alien 
life or something like that (you really lost all credibility at that 
point). We will colonize space at our own rate, and as and when it becomes 
necessary. It will not be worth it in terms of resources, but we may have 
exhausted those on Earth and it may be necessary. That is the entire scope 
on the matter, and youtube comments from people who have no qualifications 
on the matter aren't going to be considered credible arguments to attest 
for or against that. You may as well have been theorising a realisation of 
an Alcubierre drive.

comments.text:

like my idea - ignore it. 

By the way - why youtube - because its the only place where I can freely 
say things like this. I dont have the power required to do anything... Im

voice means nothing for such a wide world. 

If my ideas offended you Im sorry, but if you dont agree with my ideas, 
then I hope you should ask yourself what humanity really wants. We dont 
need to survive - we need to thrive. We know nothing about the full majesty 
of space - maybe space has more intelligent life forms than one can even 
imagine. I dont want my future descendants to show this other beings how 
aggressive we are - for this may cause them to treat us as a threat. I 
believe that inorder for the rest of humanity to coexist with other beings 
- mutual understanding must be attained between the lives of space. 

And you might think that this is quite out of topic, this is the extension 
of my proposed idea of exploring space. For years, we are sending out our 
information to space. Maybe aliens are tuning their radars into Earth and 
are listening to Hitler's speeches or to the radio transmissions during the 
Cuban Crisis.Anyway, whatever those dudes out there in space are receiving,

expensive step for all of humanity to take - but this only step we have to 
ensure survival of the race. I hope you understand what I mean.

comments.text:
You literally asked me if I was qualified to talk about such things. I 
replied by saying I have a physics degree, and so yes I am qualified. You 
then persist in telling my how a scientist should think, and that I am 
wrong, and not a scientist. I don't even have to ask at this point, whether 
you have an educated background. Scientists build their hypotheses on 
educated and peer-reviewed facts and articles.

My favourite bit is "build other things much more faster. Afterall, that 
what weve been doing all the time." Aside from the basic lack of coherent 
sentence structure there, you're wrong in every way. The LHC has jut 
restarted after being upgraded-our greatest scientific approach to dark 
matter, Higgs field realisation, etc (I'm sure you will be reading this all 
on wkipedia).

"I'm targeting everyone on this world - trying to say to the world that we 
must hurry on going up to space before we threaten ourselves with 
annihilation with our own hands or by the Earth's fury."

1- Targeting the whole world via a youtube comment is not a viable attempt.

to you. Get a degree?

2- The Earth's fury? Really? Even from a Geophysical standpoint, that makes 
no sense. As I mentioned earlier, you are completely talking in metaphors 
and avoiding the arguments I am proposing to you.

"You may have earn a physics degree, but your an embarrassment to the 
scientific community. Science is an open topic - not a closed one. Science 
is flexible, not hard. Science is a very wide and vast topic - so vast it 
encompasses everything in our modern lives."

2- Until you are able to form a concise argument that is not filled with

is a compliment, as somebody like you, who quotes the big freeze as the

comments.text:
Think of gravity as a bubble and the object exerting the gravity (in this 
case the sun)  is at the center. The sun is always exerting more bubble, to 
maintain its bubble of gravity. We as a planet are in that bubble circling 
around the center of the bubble. This established, nothing can travel 
faster than the speed of light, even gravity cannot "travel" faster than 
light. However, gravity does travel around the speed of light, so the point 
where the sun stopped exerting bubble would be when we moved out of orbit 
and also around the same time the sun's light would stop reaching us.

top_comment.text:
When it comes to no sun you would not be able to survive, kind of, well let 
me explain.... - Vitamin D is only obtained from sunlight, and is vital. 
Without the sun, we would all be Vitamin D deficient, and therefore 
deficient in other things too - like Potassium and Calcium (which will also 
become deficient since Vitamin D helps absorb it). Because of this, we 
would pose many health problems - not to mention issues with our skin. We 
would also suffer from depression (or other depressive disorders) because 
sunlight is vital for creating the neurotransmitter, serotonin, which 
evaluates our mood. Without it, we would all spiral down, a large majority 
of us even committing suicide. Basically in short, if the sun suddenly went 
out - we humans would not survive. We have evolved, and therefore adapted 
for the environment we currently live in.

If, however, the loss of sunlight was slow and gradual overtime, then the 
rising of a possibly mutation would change our eye and skin anatomy - given 
we were able to adapt. We could possibly adapt an amazing ability to take 
in minimum Vitamin D, or perhaps not need it at all! Imagine what on earth 
our skins would look like!

Why do you have skin colors? Its because of melatonin in reponse to 
sunlight. As the sun gradually disappeared, we would have no need for the 
skin colors we have today. We would possibly all look ghostly white, and 
have to develop thicker skin to adapt to the coldness we'd have without 
sunlight. Here evolution could experiment with skin.

A very important one concerning eyes - eyes evolved to detect light. 
Without it, suppose we had no other light source on earth? Remember, the 
moon does not give off light - it reflects the suns light. We could end up 
developing smaller eyes (as they would have no use to us any more), or 
loose them all together! We would definatly lose color vision as primates - 
this has been a very important evolutionary feature in primates who need to 
make judgements on picking food (imagine not being able to tell which fruit 
was ripe or which was poisionous)!

There are many implications to this question, and I have only touched on 
SOME of them. We could perhaps look like pale, thick skinned, hairy, 
eyeless creatures without sunlight. Have fun imagining the rest!﻿

comments.text:
+Masian TIdal forces are a kind of stretching force that results from 
gravitational gradients. They are stronger closer to a gravitational body 
because the gradient is more intense. The moon pulls on the part of Earth 
closest to it slightly more than the part of Earth furthest from it. The 
net result is a tidal force, essentially a force that "stretches" the Earth 
toward/away from the Moon. The oceans respond to this, creating the "tides".

The gravity gradients close to the event horizon of a black hole are 
extreme enough that the tidal force would be enough to pull a human being 
apart. The black hole would be pulling on your feet so much harder than 
your head, that it would pull you apart.

star" (which was the original term), and is thus a super massive star 
who's gravitational pull is to strong for light to escape (hence being 
dark).
If a planet were to fall into the gravitational neighborhood of a black 
hole it wouldn't coalesce into a planet, it would fall into the star and be 
crushed into it.
Gravitational pull in close proximity to large bodies are called tidal 
forces.
The tidal forces around a black hole are an either/or thing. You're either 
in them OR you're not.
tl;dr 
No. If something were close to a black hole it would be eaten by it. Also 
no radiative energy to support life.
comments.author: Masian

collision are very slim.  Even for a body the size of our planet.  For 
instance, the asteroids around Saturn are nearly 500,000 miles apart from 
the closest one.  When you take probability into consideration; when was 
the last time something so massive actually damaged earth?  The odds of us 
hitting another orbital body, or just an asteroid/comet, are about the same 
as right now, as we spin in orbit around the sun.

comments.text:
To Cecilia Terille: You asked: "What do plants get out of sun exactly?" One 
thing and one thing ONLY! PHOTONS. In the presence of CHLOROPHYLL a little 
dance takes place. It's complicated, hang in there. In the leaf there's a 
molecule called adenosine diphosphate. There's other molecules with 
phosphorous. The photon strikes the outer electron layer of the other 
phosphorous and raises that layer to a higher energy state. The chlorophyll 
facilitates the coupling of that higher phosphorous with the adenosine 
diphosphate, creating ATP! Adenosine TRIphosphate. We eat the plants or we 
eat the animals that ate the plants. We digest the ATP. It releases that 
extra photon locked in the higher energy state of the outer electron layer. 
That photon moves a muscle cell causing it to contract. And ten thousand 
other things. This allows LIFE. Chlorophyll brings starlight into our 
bodies and cells allowing them to be ALIVE. Get a biology book and really 
read what goes on. I learned this in high school science. You should have 
too.
comments.author: KitCox

comments.text:
We don't need to turn a planet into a spaceship. You are not Sephiroth or 
Jenova. You do not need to ride entire planets through the cosmos, hoping 
to find a new world to taint.

There's something to be said for having a relatively stationary base of 
operations. You want to explore? Great. When Europeans were exploring the 
 New World they didn't try to sail their entire countries across the ocean. 
For good reason... that'd be straight up retarded.

I don't know why I'm even responding. The idea that we should use planets 
as ships is literally one of the most retarded notions I've ever 
entertained for more than a second. Okay. Sorry. But seriously:.. we've 
made things go faster than the Earth's orbit around the sun: if I'm not 
mistaken, the maximum orbital velocity of the Helios probes around the sun 
was more than twice the speed of Earth's. 

You'd also need to either make the sun vanish (yeah, good luck) or generate 
enough force to PUSH AN ENTIRE PLANET OUT OF THE SUN'S ORBIT.

There is one thing to be said for your idea - it'd overcome the problem of 
cosmic radiation if we used Earth. Our magnetic field is a proven remedy 
for space radiation. I mean escaping the sun would also kill off like 99% 
of humanity (and pretty much all extant species that we didn't choose to 
save), but the remaining handful... yeah they'd be travelling... remarkably 
slow, still. Even if we could choose our destination, say... the closest 
neighbouring solar system... the people who initiated the plan would 
probably be dead before they arrived. So... not a great idea. Not even an 
idea. It's more like brain diarrhoea and you should seriously get that 
checked out.

comments.text:
Basically, there's a one in X chance of anything happening. Things like 
flipping a coin and getting heads are one in two, things like getting a 
natural twenty on a twenty-sided-die are one in twenty, and so on. Quantum 
tunneling is when something happens on a spontaneous chance of one in 
what's practically infinity, and in an almost inconceivable and completely 
improbable scenario matter spontaneously teleports, or tunnels, from one 
place to the next. On a small scale given the number of atoms in the 
universe, this happens all the time, but it's insanely unlikely that every 
atom in the sun could reach the wildly improbable chance of quantum 
tunneling.

comments.author: Jordan Allen

comments.text:
The sun's energy can be described like a massive nuclear fusion chamber 
that consumes a large range of elements.

I have found a small list of elements, but there is a possibility of more 
elements that we haven't documented or discovered that could be found in 
our own sun.

http://www.space.com/17170-what-is-the-sun-made-of.html

There would be many factors that would act against us if we decide to 
replicate our own sun.

Heat, Gravitational Pull, Initiating the Fusion between the elements, 
Gathering the necessary amount of each element, and other similar types of 
problems would likely occur in the process of making our own sun.

We could attempt to create a smaller star, but then you would come across 
the issue that the amount of energy required to replace our own sun would 
quickly consume the smaller man-made star in a matter of months to years 
depending on the amount of resources we decide to put into it.

If we do come across the issue of losing our own sun, the first bit of 
importance would be self-defense against numerous rioters and possibly 
putting forth a combined effort into making use of the thermal energy 
within Earth's crust and mantle.

We would also have to find a new source of food after the plants died off 
without photosynthesis. One could argue that we could use UV bulbs to grow 
plants for subsistence farming, but we would still lose a lot of nutrients 
because certain plants would be too costly to grow and would take too long 
to produce. Our diets would mainly consist of grains such as rice and 
starches, with little to no meat aside from cannibalism.

The psychological factors of such an event could also be catastrophic, 
especially due to the possibility of losing large quantities of life on 
Earth within 5 to 10 years. Loneliness would be common-placed and 
dependencies on others would increase tremendously in order to maintain 
sanity. (Wilson would serve as a fine substitute for human interaction, but 
a volleyball would still fail to meet our basic social requirements)

With these sudden changes, the average lifespan would drastically shift 
from the current ~71 years to much lower values due to the fact that 
newborns and young children will not be capable of surviving long after 
birth without certain required nutrients from a varied diet. An infant 
could survive on breast milk for years, but the supplier would have to take 
in extra nutrients and food in order to build a sufficient supply for 
another being.

Making our own sun wouldn't be a possibility given the modern limitations 
in technology and science, even though we can replicate the nuclear fusion 
that goes on in our own sun, we will not be capable of gathering anywhere 
near the amount of energy to make an exact duplicate sun.

comments.text:
+kristian perez
Ok, try this: Take all the components of a laptop computer: cpu, memory 
sticks, motherboard, screen components, hard disk, external chassis, 
screws, etc etc etc..... and put them all in a plastic bag. Now shake the 
bag, until you obtain a fully assembled laptop from the bag.

Some evolutionists have argued to me: "yeah, but appearance of life and/or 
evolution has happened over billions of years!!"

Assuming the earth is 4.something billion years old, do you think you'll 
obtain a fully assembled laptop even if you keep shaking the bag for 4.xx 
billion years?

Ok, for those who argue that "abiogenesis" is a completely separate concept 
from "evolution", the same - well, similar - argument still applies. Any 
form of mutation can be compared to a bomb exploding, and causing 
completely random changes at the DNA level. Mutations are *never* helpful 
to the organism suffering them. If you rounded up all the material to build 
a house on a construction ground and then blow it up with dynamite, do you 
think you'll get a perfectly built house, with all its wiring in place, 
furniture landing exactly in the right places, and so on? Or that you ever 
will, even if you repeat this trillions and trillions of times? Personally 
i've never heard of a bomb explosion "improving" the structure of a 
building. *Another interesting topic* is the mutation experiments they did 
with x-rays on several millions of fruit flies (drosophila flies) for 
dozens of years, ending in the mid 80's -- the x-rays multiplied the factor 
of mutation by over 100. Once removed from the x-rays, after a few 
generations, even heavily mutated fruit flies became, guess what: back to 
normal fruit flies.

As for Darwin's slow, progressive changes between species - ie. so called 
"natural selection": 1. as i noted above, we have scientific proof that 
didn't happen, and zero proof that it actually did, and 2. If it did, then 
why are there still monkeys? How come they didn't all evolve into humans or 
human-like lifeforms? Why are they all at the same "evolutionary stage" so 
to speak?

And most importantly, why is there so much debate and disagreement even 
between evolution experts? Why don't even they agree about whose 
"scientific method" is the right one?

comments.text:
+PicturaSonus If evolution was a fact, we would have found fossil records 
that prove it: missing links between every species and the next. We haven't 
found a single one. This is why these "transition" drawings are just that, 
drawings purely out of the human imagination, and not pictures of actual 
fossils - because obviously we have no such fossil records. For examle, if 
the giraffe was really a "descendant" of the antilope, why don't we have 
fossils of antilopes with progressively longer necks? We only have 
illustrations drawn by evolutionists trying to hammer the idea into the 
public's mind - and sadly, widely succeeding at that.

In the introduction to his book "the origin of species", Darwin himself 
admitted that the absence of such fossils would contradict his entire 
theory. He predicted that within 100 years of writing this book, we would 
have found every fossil proving his theory. Like i said, we have found 
none. He also claimed that proof of sudden appearances of groups of similar 
species would also destroy his theory. This is what archaeologists also 
found actually happened.

One thing about carbon dating: the amount of carbon 14 in the earth's 
atmosphere has only been "relatively" constant in the past 6000 to 10000 
years, before that it varied wildly. This has led to gross errors in carbon 
dating of some specimens.
comments.author: delt01

comments.text:

evolutionary biologists or simply people who accept the theory of 
evolution) acknowledge this is because we're not even talking about 
evolution. We're talking about abiogenesis. A hypothesis (rather, a 
concept) which has much more speculation involved than evolution, which is 
absolutely a demonstrable fact.

All I've heard you say in your entire collection of statements can be 
summed up by saying "evolution is far too complex and seemingly unlikely 
for my mind to comprehend, therefore, the God hypothesis is far more likely 
and also much more pleasant." As Neil deGrasse Tyson has said before, the 
God of the Gaps is no God at all. The more science advances and covers 
areas we knew nothing about, the more the God of the Gaps disappears.

If you wish to argue with science, you need to play by its rules and

comments.text:
+ParanormalCacti It is a scientific impossibility that a living cell would 
appear out of inanimate matter, even in the span of 4.something billion 
years, even in the perfect living conditions. I don't think you realize how 
extremely complex even the simplest living cell is. Compared to it, even 
the most powerful man-made supercomputer is nothing but sticks and stones. 
And, even IF by some miracle a living cell popped into existence, this does 
not solve the problem of its environment, a single living cell would never 
have been able to survive for very long in this "big mush pool of pre-life 
earth". And that's just the very first problem with the evolution theory. 
Even many evolutionists acknowledge these facts.

As for other life-sustaining planets in the universe, the balance of all 
the different parameters that make life possible on earth is just too 
extremely perfect. Just for example, the moon's axis around the earth is a 
tremendously precise feat. It was clearly NOT caused simply by large bodies 
crashing together in space - that's just ridiculous when you look deeper 
into it. Another example is the earth's atmosphere, which is carefully 
designed to shield us from dangerous rays from the sun, while at the same 
time absorbing vital ones. Plus, even if there was life on other planets, 
it would just be so unimaginably far away that it just wouldn't even 
concern us, period. Real life isn't a sci-fi movie.

And yes, evolutionism has become nothing more than another false religion. 
It takes a LOT more so-called "faith" to belive it, than to believe the 
universe was created by a supremely intelligent and creative Architect.
comments.author: delt01

comments.text:
Life appearing from inanimate matter is not as unlikely as you might think. 
It is still unlikely, thus why it took billions of years after the earth 
formed to happen. Elements react as they always have in the big mush pool 
of pre-life earth and a lucky combination of carbon and other elements fall 
into a self-sustaining cycle that allows them to satisfy their reactivity 
needs in an effective system. Thus you have the natural will of life to, 
well, stay alive. So because the conditions required for a planet to 
sustain life and for that life to occur are so astronomically small, do you 
think we are special? That there is someone kind of divine intervention? In 
case you weren't aware, there are trillions and trillions of planets in the 
universe which means that the odds of there being NO life are drastically 
smaller than there being life. Of course there are still some unanswered 
questions about evolution, but I would just like to clean up some your 
ignorance. Also you should probably be careful with certain words such as 
calling evolution a religion. Scientists are merely trying to answer 
questions with consistent logic, and if any evidence suggested that life 
were impossible without divine intervention, then evolutionists would no 
longer hold faith in evolution, much unlike how a religion acts.
comments.author: ParanormalCacti

top_comment.text:
Can you imagine an intelligent, extra-terrestrial race scouting the 
universe for alien life and finally finding a cold, desolate, planet 
covered in seas of frozen.......water! They scout the planet for signs of 
life and they find it.....everywhere! But only in fossil form. Dead 
bacteria and strange aquatic life all dead and preserved in the ice. They 
scout the very few landmasses and find what looks like buildings! They must 
have been created by some sort of intelligent life form! But they are dated 
to be billions of years old (they are very well preserved). They find 
strange skeletons, they appear to be designed to walk upright. They have an 
incredibly large brain to body ratio so the aliens confirm they must have 
been the intelligent life here. They send the skeletons up to the mother 
ship for initial testing along with all the other samples, sadly wondering 
if they were too late. If their first and most incredible discovery of 
alien life would never come to the discovery of actual, living life. In awe 
and wondering if there was any actual, still living creatures on this 
planet they scout the entire planet's surface. They find something 
remarkable! The planet has an unstable crust, this means fault lines... 
Which means there could possibly be pockets of unfrozen, even warm, H2O due 
to underwater volcanic activity! Excited, they scan the oceans and find 
exactly that! They decend down to the planet yet again and begin the plasma 
drill through 16 kilometres of ice. Two days later they reach a safe haven 
if warm water. They decend into the alien liquid and scout it for 
life...and they eventually find it! Hardy sea plants capable of surviving 
the pressures and lack of life down here. The aliens return to their home 
planet and report their incredible find to the public. The media is 
overloaded by the greatest discovery in their existence and the population 
is swept. Their are conspiracy theorys of it all being made up but 
eventually some of the fossils are sold to museums for the public's 
viewing. A crowd of pre-mature school aliens huddle around a glass case 
containing one of the skeletons of the extinct, intelligent aliens. They 
read the plaque:
"_~\|\*~\~~\_~\*\*~~*\~_\*~_~~~_~\_~~_~~_~~*\|::/"
"The first instance of an upright, opposable thumbed creature with a large 
brain to body ratio. These creatures are thought to have built the billions 
of structures found on 'Frozen Orb 001-9'. They could have very well been 
actual, intelligent, alien life."
The aliens continue to live their lives and shape the fate if their own 
planet. The discovery launches a great change in the public's opinion of 
space exploration. Governments around the world fund trillions of dollars 
into further exploration, scouting the universe for any other possible 
remnants of this strange, extinct, intelligent life. The only thing they 
ever find is a stiff, frozen flag and a few strange footprints on the 
planet's lone moon.
﻿

this. Our sun is around 1,400,000km across. I think the furthest out known 
dwarf planet is Eris (at this distance if the earth or moon found a stable 
orbit the difference between the strength on each wouldn't break them up) 
is 1.442×10^10km. Our nearest star is 4.011 × 10^13km.

The chance of getting close enough to a massive enough body that the 
relative gravitational effect was enough to separate them is absolutely 
miniscule. The chance of an actual collision is virtually nil.

comments.text:
The sun isn't large enough to produce a black hole or even a supernova at 
it's death time. Within the next four billion years, the sun will expand, 
transforming into a red giant. When this happens, all life on the planet 
will die, as the sun will swallow Earth while expanding. After it's 
expansion, our star will then shrink into a "white dwarf" star, about the 
size of Earth. Finally, it will just... burn out.

A very large star (much larger than our star), however, would have a much 
more violent death. It would explode in a supernova of preposterous 
proportions. After the explosion, what's left of the star is, you guessed 
it, a black hole.

Earth won't have to worry about being sucked into a black hole, but rather 
about being burned alive by our own sun. Don't worry though, we still have 
a couple billion more years. Our oceans will completely evaporate before 
then anyway.

top_comment.text:
*What If The Sun Just Totally Disappeared?*

This is actually a pretty great thought experiment. At first it might seem 
kind of pointless to talk about what would happen if the sun vanished, but 
it doesn't actually result in the immediate destruction of everything. 
Which is weird. Vsauce walks through a pretty nuanced description of how 
earth's natural systems would slowly fail, but over weeks and even years, 
not seconds. The cold would get us in the end, but extremophiles that live 
in deep sea volcanoes and thermal vents could survive for billions of 
years. If you're not heliocentric and human-centric things don't look so 
bleak. 

Read More:
http://gizmodo.com/5993063/what-if-the-sun-just-totally-disappeared﻿

comments.text:
Ha. How do we know Earth didn't once orbit a star that vanished.... That's 
easy. Stars don't just vanish.

Seriously though, it is possible for a planet to break away from a solar 
system. It is usually in the early stages of a solar system and the planet 
is most likely not evolved much yet. Some of the fasted celestial objects 
are rogue planets slung from a snagged stars of a binary star system when 
it's star gets grabbed up by a black hole. Unfortunately these are very 
hard to detect and we most likely will never see them in our lifetime. But 
science can prove they must exist. Any rogue planet has very little chance 
of sneaking into a solar system and finding a nice orbit but they have a 
worse chance of fitting it. We can tell how old things are. We know that 
Earth is about as old as our solar system. Shucks. We are most likely not 
adopted. 
A cool thing to note is all the heavier elements that make up our solar 
system was spat our of a dying star. So technically parts of the Earth did 
travel the solar system to find their (current) resting spot.

If we were to survive the cold by living around thermal vents and using 
fossil fuels, we probably wouldn't live a whole lot longer than a year. The 
plants would be dead within a couple of days (refer to video) except for 
the trees. That means that a major food source is gone. Any food chain 
eventually goes back to plants meaning all other animals would die out 
(assuming the cold didn't take them first, starvation would get them real 
fast). We would only be able to live as long as our current food supply is 
able to sustain us.﻿

captions.text: Hey, Vsauce. Michael here.

Gravity is a property of matter, anything
with mass. This includes the Moon, Earth,

Jupiter, the Sun, and even you - your body.
In fact, if you kinda like somebody, have

them stand 3/4 of a millimeter away from you.
At that distance, cumulatively, every atom

in your body and every atom in their body
will draw you two together with the same gravitational
force that the Sun is exerting on you right now.

Of course, we don't feel either of those forces
because compared to the gravitational influence

of the Earth, they are basically nothing.
You don't need to concern yourself with the gravitational

attraction between you and someone you're
hugging, or, your individual body and the

Sun, 150 million kilometres away.
In fact, the Sun may as well not exist.
What if the Sun disappeared?

Well, to be sure, it's not going to happen.
The Sun will die billions of years from now

by expanding, boiling off our oceans
and swallowing the Earth whole.

The Sun is not going to simply disappear.
Matter and energy don't vanish. Of course,

matter can quantum tunnel to different locations,
but on the scale of the Sun there is not

enough time in the lifetime of millions and
billions of universes for such a probability
to even be worth discussing.

But let's discuss it anyway, as a thought
experiment to determine how the Earth would

get along with no Sun.
What will the Earth do and what can it do alone?

At the exact moment that the Sun disappeared,
we would have no idea. Because it takes light

from the Sun 8 minutes and 20 seconds to
reach Earth. So, for a little over 8 minutes

after the Sun disappeared, we would have no
idea. Once we did, confusion and mass panic
would, most likely, ensue.

The Sun's gravitational grasp on our planet
would also take 8 minutes and 20 seconds to

end. This is because gravity waves propagate
at the speed of light. So, the very moment

we saw our Sun disappear, we would also lose
its gravitational influence and Earth would

fly out in a straight line,
tangent to wherever it was in its orbit.

The finite speed of light and gravity mean
that as panic and fear spread across the Earth

at the loss of our Sun, we could still, for
a while, look up into the sky and see our planetary

buddies, further out, continuing to operate
as if nothing had happened.

For instance, Jupiter would continue orbiting
and reflecting light from a Sun that no longer

existed for about 30 minutes after the Earth
already knew the Sun was gone. And, depending

on where Jupiter was in its orbit, it would
take another 30 minutes to an hour for us
to watch the reflected light of Jupiter snuff out.

With no moonlight or sunlight, the universe
itself would be our only source of visible
light from space.

In 2004, Abdul Ahad calculated that the Milky
Way contributes about as much light as 1/300th

of a full Moon. So there would be enough light
from space for us to see around a bit. But,

of course, electricity and fossil fuels would
still be usable for a while. So, cities and

towns could continue to be lit by manmade
sources, just like a typical night; except,
it would be night everywhere.

Photosynthesis would stop immediately, and
this is huge. I had a great discussion about

this video with Henry from MinutePhysics,
and the new channel MinuteEarth. If you're
not subscribed to MinuteEarth, you definitely should be.

In one of his episodes there, he mentions
that 99.9% of the natural productivity on

Earth is done by photosynthesis, which requires
the Sun. Without the Sun, plants would no

longer be able to inhale carbon dioxide and
exhale life-sustaining oxygen.

But, don't worry. Collectively, all of us
humans, all 7 billion of us, breathe in about

6 trillion kilos of oxygen every year.
But our atmosphere contains a whopping quintillion

kilos of oxygen. So, even without photosynthesis,
and, including all the other animals, and

insects, and microorganisms that consume oxygen,
it would take us thousands of years to run
out.

The poor plants themselves would be much
worse off. Without the Sun, most of them would

die within days or weeks. Except for large
plants. Giants trees, for instance, contain

enough sugar for energy that they could technically
live in the dark for years. Their problem

is going to be that the Earth will get quite
cold. In fact, mighty trees would freeze to

death. Their blood, the water and sap inside
of them, solidify way before they died of starvation.

Right now, with our Sun, the average surface
temperature on Earth, hot places and cold

places, and different seasons all considered,
is an arguably comfortable 14 to 15 degrees
Celsius.

Without the Sun to add energy, the Earth would
radiate away heat exponentially, meaning

it would go fast at first and then happen
more and more slowly. By the end of the first

week without the Sun, the average surface
temperature across Earth would be freezing.

Zero Celsius, 32 degrees Fahrenheit. 
Now, temperature's like this happen all the time

on Earth, we're used to it. Panic and fear 
and looters and anarchy aside, for the first
few days or months, we could get by.

But by the end of the first year without
the Sun, the average global surface temperature
would be -73 degrees Celsius, -100 Fahrenheit.

The best option, really, would be to move
to geothermal areas like Yellowstone or Iceland.

These places would be the few safe havens
for human life after the Sun. Nearly all life

on Earth exists because of, and is dependent
upon, extraterrestrial energy: the Sun. But

the Earth produces its own heat. Despite floating
in the coldness of space for billions of years,
down below the crust the Earth is quite warm.

20% of this warmth came from the fact that
when the Earth formed, mass crushed so tightly

in the middle that the pressure liquified rock.
The other 80% of Earth's internal heat

comes from that fact that deep in its core,
radioactive elements decay, providing the

energy needed to keep the Earth's core at
5,000 degrees Celsius.

Anyone who failed to secure a position within
one of these bastions of warmth, or, perhaps,

underground in a community warmed and powered
by nuclear fuel, would likely be dead within
the first year of no Sun.

In the next 10 or 20 years things would start
to get wet with dew. But not with glorious

water droplets. Instead, droplets of liquid air.
The air would literally become cold enough

for the gasses that make it up to condense,
or form clouds and precipitate, first as rain,

and then as it got colder and colder,
eventually, as snow.

In Fritz Leiber's famous science-fiction short
story "A Pail of Air," this has already happened.

The Earth was ripped away from the Sun, and,
in order to survive, a family must go outdoors

in a special suit and scoop up a pale of just
the oxygen snow, bring it back in, and place
it over a fire to warm and allow them to breathe.

A year or so after the sun disappeared, Earth's
oceans will have frozen over. Ice all the

way across. But ice is less dense than liquid
water, which means that ice floats. And ice

is a pretty decent insulator.
So, for billions of years after the Sun disappeared, liquid

water could still exist at the bottom of our
oceans, protected and insulated from space

by miles of ice above it, and warmed by vents
on the ocean floor that spew water out, super
heated by Earth's interior.

This would continue on Earth for a very, very
long time - Sun or no Sun. Instead of becoming

frozen and lifeless, extremophiles, like microbes,
that live around hydrothermal vents deep in

the ocean, would be fine. They live deep in
the ocean, far below the point where sunlight

can penetrate, and they make energy not through
photosynthesis, but via chemosynthesis - converting

heat and methane and sulphur into the energy
they need. They are then eaten by clams and
tubeworms.

Extremophiles deposit minerals back into the
vents, meaning that their food chain is complete.

It's a circle. It's independent of the Sun.
Earthlings like them would thrive if the Sun

were to disappear. They would live just fine
without every knowing that the Sun was gone.

Or, honestly, without ever even knowing it
existed in the first place.

It's amazing to think that life, here on Earth,
all alone, flying through space with no Sun,

would kind of be fine. Far from becoming a
frozen dead rock, or a boring dormant seed,

the Earth would be a spaceship, carrying living
passengers with enough geothermal heat for
billions of years of life.

If the Sun disappeared, spaceship Earth would
fly out in a straight line covering about

30 kilometres every single second. After just 1 billion
years, it will have covered 900 quadrillion

kilometres or about 100,000 lightyears - a trip that
could potentially take it all the way across

our galaxy, near thousands of stars.
And nothing's to say it couldn't fall into orbit around one,

thaw out, and allow its still-living extremophiles
to proliferate life on Earth all over again;

maybe one day developing life intelligent
enough to uncover whatever is left of our

lives.
Maybe they could even find this very video.
In which case, hi, uh, you're welcome
for this video about your planet's history and journey.
And, um, as always,
thanks for watching.
